terms.title: Action Chess
terms.description: A game where each player only has 30 minutes to make all his moves.

terms.title: Algebraic Notation
terms.description: A method for writing moves down by using the names of the pieces and the ranks and files. Replaced older Descriptive Notation (“P-K4" is now "e4") about 1970.

terms.title: Amateur
terms.description: In chess, a non-master. At the US Amateur, masters cannot play; at the US Amateur Team tournaments, the team has to average below master rating. Note: in chess, amateurs can win money, sometimes quite a bit, at tournaments like the World Open.

terms.title: Attack
terms.description: When you move a piece to a square where you could capture an opponent’s piece NEXT move.

terms.title: Back Rank
terms.description: The rank where a player sets up his major pieces (1st for White; 8th for Black).

terms.title: Back-Rank Mate
terms.description: A checkmate on the 1st or 8th rank with a Rook or Queen.

terms.title: Battery
terms.description: Lining up two pieces that move similarly, like a Queen and Rook or Queen and Bishop.

terms.title: Blitz
terms.description: Fast chess. Many blitz games are 5 minutes per player for the entire game.

terms.title: Book
terms.description: Besides the kind with a spine, a “book” move is one that a player has learned to play in a particular position in the opening (from a “book” or other media) without the need to “calculate”.

terms.title: Blunder
terms.description: A bad move; primarily a move that turns a win into a loss or draw, or a draw into a loss.

terms.title: Bughouse
terms.description: A variant of chess with two players on each side – a player gets the pieces his partner captures.

terms.title: Bye
terms.description: What you get when you can’t play a round, but are still continuing to play in the tournament. Byes don’t count for ratings, but can be either 0 points, ½ point, or 1 point (in case you want to play, but are the odd person available).

terms.title: Capture
terms.description: (or Take) not Kill – to remove a piece from the board via a legal move.

terms.title: Castle
terms.description: To move your unmoved King 2 squares toward an unmoved Rook and to move the Rook on the other side of the King is the castling move.

terms.title: Check
terms.description: An attack on the King. You do not have to announce “check”.

terms.title: Checkmate
terms.description: An attack on the King where there is no way for your opponent to finish his turn and no longer have the King attacked. To be checkmated.

terms.title: CTD
terms.description: Club Tournament Director.

terms.title: Desperado
terms.description: A piece that is going to be captured anyway so it can "sacrifice" itself at the highest cost.

terms.title: Discovery
terms.description: An attack by a piece that was opened up via another piece’s move.

terms.title: Double Attack
terms.description: An attack on two (or more) pieces by a single move.

terms.title: Doubled Pawns
terms.description: Two pawns of the same color on the same file as a result of a capture.

terms.title: Doubled Rooks
terms.description: Two Rooks forming a battery on a rank or file.

terms.title: Draw
terms.description: Any game that ends without either player winning, e.g. Stalemate, Lack of Mating Material, 50-Move Rule, etc. The word 'tie' is not used.

terms.title: En Passant
terms.description: Capturing a pawn that moved 2 spaces with a pawn that could have captured it if it had only moved 1 space, on the next turn only.

terms.title: En Prise
terms.description: Literally 'in take' - able to be captured for free. A piece is en prise if it can be captured but is not guarded.

terms.title: Endgame
terms.description: The part of the game where the King should come out and fight (with fewer pieces left on the board). The ending phase of chess.

terms.title: Expert
terms.description: Someone with a US Chess Federation rating between 2000 and 2199.

terms.title: Exchange
terms.description: Trading pieces, usually of equal value. Also trading ('winning') a Rook for a Knight or Bishop is to be 'up the Exchange'.

terms.title: Fianchetto
terms.description: To develop a Bishop on a long diagonal (b2 or g2 for White; b7 or g7 for Black).

terms.title: FIDE
terms.description: International Chess Federation.

terms.title: FIDE Master
terms.description: Someone with the lowest International Chess Title.

terms.title: Fifty-Move Rule
terms.description: A type of draw where both players make 50 moves consecutively without either player advancing a pawn or making a capture.

terms.title: File
terms.description: The rows of a chess board going up and down, lettered a-h (lower case), with 'a' always on White’s left (and Black’s right).

terms.title: Five Minute/Blitz
terms.description: A game where each player has five minutes to make all his moves.

terms.title: Flag
terms.description: The part of an analog clock that rises when the minute hand nears the hour and falls at the hour. As a verb, 'to flag' means to lose the game on time.

terms.title: Fool’s Mate
terms.description: A 2-move mate similar to 1.f3?? e5 2.g4??? Qh4#.

terms.title: Forfeit
terms.description: When a player doesn't show up for a game he is forfeit and loses.

terms.title: Fork
terms.description: A double attack, usually by a Knight or Pawn (thus looking like a “fork” in the road), a common chess tactic.

terms.title: Grandmaster
terms.description: Someone with the highest International Chess Title.

terms.title: Illegal Move
terms.description: A move that either a) Moves a piece in an illegal manner, or 2) Results in an illegal position.

terms.title: International Master
terms.description: Someone with the intermediate International Chess Title.

terms.title: Isolated Pawns
terms.description: Pawns that have no other pawns of the same color on adjacent files are isolated and 'alone', lacking support by fellow pawns.

terms.title: Knight
terms.description: The chess piece that moves like an 'L', or the shortest move that is not a straight one.

terms.title: LTD
terms.description: Local Tournament Director.

terms.title: Master
terms.description: Someone with a US Chess Federation rating between 2200 and 2399.

terms.title: Material
terms.description: A way to determine piece value; or the winning of a pawn (or piece, or Exchange) means winning 'material'.

terms.title: NTD
terms.description: National Tournament Director.

terms.title: Open File
terms.description: A file with no pawns of either color.

terms.title: Patzer
terms.description: A 'fish' or weak chess player.

terms.title: Piece
terms.description: Any of the chessmen; a set of chess pieces. Sometimes non-pawns only, 'pieces and pawns'.

terms.title: Pin
terms.description: An attack (by a Rook, Bishop or Queen) on a piece that cannot or should not move, because a piece behind the attacked piece is worth even more. If the piece behind is a King, this is an 'absolute' pin and the pinned piece is not allowed to move, or it would put the King into check.

terms.title: Ply
terms.description: A half-move, or the move of one player. When both players move, that is two ply, or one full move.

terms.title: Promote
terms.description: When a pawn reaches the other side of the board, the 8th rank, it can promote to a Queen, Rook, Bishop, or Knight on the promoting square.

terms.title: Rank
terms.description: The rows of a chessboard going sideways, numbered 1st-8th starting from White’s side as 1st.

terms.title: Rating
terms.description: A measure of skill. USCF Ratings range from roughly 0 (basically impossible to get this low - no one ever has) to 3000; most scholastic beginners start around 400. Even if you lose all your games in your first few tournaments you are still usually about 200.

terms.title: Repetition
terms.description: A type of draw where the same position is reached three times with the same player to move. Does not require the same moves and can occur at any point in the game.

terms.title: Resigns
terms.description: When you purposely turn down your King or say 'I resign' – the game is over and you lose. Note that shaking hands does not end a game.

terms.title: Round Robin
terms.description: A system of pairing players where everyone in the same (small) section plays everyone else. Unlike the swiss system, this type of tournament calls for some level of commitment on the part of the players to attempt to complete all their games.

terms.title: Scholar’s Mate
terms.description: To mate on f7 (or, for Black, f2) with a Queen or a Bishop in 4 moves – usually a very bad thing to try. When teaching about this, Dan calls this 'Dumb and Dumber'.

terms.title: Section
terms.description: A part of a chess tournament where the players are paired together. Sections may be divided by rating class, scholastic vs. non-scholastic, rated vs. unrated, Scholastic Level, etc.

terms.title: Semi-Open File
terms.description: A file with only one pawn, belonging to the opponent.

terms.title: Senior Master
terms.description: Someone with a US Chess Federation rating over 2399.

terms.title: Skewer
terms.description: Sometimes called an 'x-ray' attack, a sort of inside-out pin. A move that attacks a piece of value, but there is a piece behind it of equal or lesser value that will be captured anyway if the attacked piece moves.

terms.title: Skittles
terms.description: Chess for fun or chess without a clock; a skittles room is where you go and play for fun while waiting for your next formal pairing.

terms.title: Stalemate
terms.description: When the player to move isn’t in check, but none of his pieces can move. This is a type of draw - but not all draws are stalemantes.

terms.title: Sudden Death
terms.description: A final time control period where the game must be completed within a certain amount of time, say 20 minutes on each player's clock.

terms.title: Swiss System
terms.description: A system of pairing tournaments whereby players are paired against opponents who are doing about as well as they are. Wherever possible, players get about an equal number of games with Black and White, and will not play the same opponent twice.

terms.title: TD
terms.description: Tournament Director.

terms.title: Tactics
terms.description: The mechanics of combining piece moves and creating threats; involving piece safety, checks, attacks, etc. Advanced tactics are considered 'combinations' of tactical motifs, such as pins, forks, removal of the guard and so forth.

terms.title: Team Tournament
terms.description: A tournament where the players play in rating order, first board against first, second against second, etc. The result is a team win, loss, or draw, depending on whether most of the players win or lose (or half of them do).

terms.title: Tempo
terms.description: The 'time' invested in developing the pieces harmoniously. A pawn is said to be worth 3 tempi, or 3 turns.

terms.title: Threat
terms.description: A move which can win material, checkmate, or make progress next move if the opponent does not stop it. Attacking an undefended piece is a possible threat.

terms.title: Time Delay
terms.description: The preferred way of using a clock at a USCF tournament; a digital clock is set to NOT run for a defined number of seconds on each move.

terms.title: Touch Move
terms.description: The rule that says if you touch a piece you have to move it. If you let go of a piece you have to leave it there, and if you purposely displace an opponent’s piece, you have to take it.

terms.title: Unrated
terms.description: An unrated player has never played a rated game, or his rating has not yet become official by the USCF (ratings become official every two months). An unrated game is one that will not be played for a rating.

terms.title: USCF
terms.description: United States Chess Federation.

terms.title: Woodpusher
terms.description: A duffer or weak chess player.

terms.title: Zugzwang
terms.description: The obligation to move, when any move at all will be bad.

terms.title: Zwischenzug
terms.description: An in-between move. For example, instead of re-capturing, a check may be given first.
